to Engineering Design and Innovation","assoc_cl_id":"3c11069adba03450fe4b322af496192b","assoc_short_title":"DPST1071 - Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2022/DPST1071","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"DPST1071","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"UNSW Global","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"DESN1000 - Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation","description":"

In this course, students will experience first hand one of the major things that engineers do: designing and building creative solutions to problems. They will learn to think the way that engineers think, coming up with good solutions to problems despite being limited by budget, time and resources, the requirement to also meet environmental and social objectives and of course the limitations of the laws of physics. This will help them to appreciate the central ideas of engineering design as an on-time, on-budget and fit for purpose solution to a poorly specified, open-ended problem. They will be assigned to a team to work over a ten week period to solve a practical problem. The projects on offer change from year to year. In doing all this they will start to build key skills for engineers that will be called upon repeatedly in their academic and professional lives, including concept development, critical thinking and evaluation skills, clear communication, research and information literacy skills and the skills involved in successfully functioning within a team environment to complete a given task.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961940","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Impromptu Design Day","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Students complete an impromptu design activity, working in teams to rapidly prototype a solution to a design challenge. Students are then assessed on an individual reflective writing task based on the activity, in a short-essay style. 

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication and reflection.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design Report and Competition","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The performance of the student team's final prototypes is evaluated by judges against a set of project-specific criteria in a competition format. 

Student teams submit a formal report which communicates their final design outcomes, including relevant competition results. Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication, quality of design process/outcomes. Team evaluation is used to ensure the equitable participation of members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a70907fadb283450be4672f5f396194e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Student teams submit a design proposal which reports on the problem definition, concept generation and concept evaluation design phases. The proposal also presents a plan for completing the project and includes any preliminary test results. 

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication, quality of design process/outcomes and project management. Team evaluation is used to ensure the equitable participation of members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b30907fadb283450be4672f5f3961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Engineering Design Process","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Student teams present the process and outcomes of their problem definition and concept generation design phases.

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include oral communication and quality of the design process and outcome. Team evaluation is used to ensure the equitable participation of members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b70907fadb283450be4672f5f396197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"15","description":"

Students keep a professional record and reflection on their design project work, which is reviewed by staff on a regular basis.

Assessment criteria will be relative to the task specification but should include written communication, design process/quality, teamwork/project management and reflection.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"270907fadb283450be4672f5f3961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bf0907fadb283450be4672f5f396195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Technical Stream","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"20","description":"

Students select a technical stream, with theory and practice assessed in relevant tasks (e.g. online quizzes, practical demonstrations, performance milestones and so on).

Assessment criteria will be relative to the technical task specification.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f0907fadb283450be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cc1907fadb283450be4672f5f3961980","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DESN1000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: In this course, students will experience first hand one of the major things that engineers do: designing and building creative solutions to problems. They will learn to think the way that engineers think, coming up with good solutions to problems despite being limited by budget, time and resources, the requirement to also meet environmental and social objectives and of course the limitations of the laws of physics. This will help them to appreciate the central ideas of engineering design as an on-time, on-budget and fit for purpose solution to a poorly specified, open-ended problem. They will be assigned to a team to work over a ten week period to solve a practical problem. The projects on offer change from year to year. In doing all this they will start to build key skills for engineers that will be called upon repeatedly in their academic and professional lives, including concept development, critical thinking and evaluation skills, clear communication, research and information literacy skills and the skills involved in successfully functioning within a team environment to complete a given task.
contentlets.title: Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DESN2000 - Engineering Design and Professional Practice","description":"

Design is one of the critical foundations of engineering and a main component in creating value. A good engineer has complex technical skills, but also creative skills, project management and teamworking skills, and knowledge of professional ethical standards in design. 


DESN2000 aims to further develop your skills in engineering design with a particular focus on the early stages, where innovative concepts are created in response to open-ended problems. These skills will be developed in the context of an engineering project, with a focus on three areas: (1) research techniques needed to understand design problems and discover concepts, (2) technical skills needed to build a concept, and (3) evaluation methods for evaluating the concept. Alongside the development of design skills, the course also aims to develop your readiness for professional practice by deepening your understanding and skills in effective project management, teamwork and communication.


The course builds on the teamwork, communication, and project management skills introduced in DESN1000. Skills learned in DESN2000 are further deepened in DESN3000, which will develop skills for managing design in commercial context.


With DESN1000 and DESN3000, DESN2000 provides design skills described in Engineers Australia’s Stage 1 Competencies, especially competencies 1.3, 1.5, 1.6; 2., 2.3; and 3.2 and 3.6.


Students who require DESN2000 should enrol in a specific term according to their Engineering Specialisation:


Term 2:
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Civil and Environmental Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Computer Science and Engineering


Term 3:
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Chemical Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Minerals and Energy Resources Engineering


Prerequisite Conditions:


  1. School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and enrolled in an MME streams (AEROAH, MECHAH, MANFAH, MTRNAH)
  2. School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and ELEC2141 and (COMP1511 or COMP1521)
  3. School of Chemical Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and CEIC2000 and (CHEM1821 or CHEM1021 or CHEM1041) 
  4. School of Civil and Environmental Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and enrolled in a Civil & Environmental Engineering streams (CVENAH, CVENBH, GMATDH)
  5. School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and SOLA 2051
  6. School of Computer Science and Engineering: (COMPBH and COMP1521 and (DESN1000 or DPST1071)) or (SENGAH/BINFAH and COMP 2521 and (DESN1000 or DPST1071))
  7. School of Minerals and Energy Resources Engineering: (MINEAH and (DESN1000 or DPST1071)) or (PETRAH and CEIC2001 and (DESN1000 or DPST1071))
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"749e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students individually keep an active, professional record and reflection of their team's design process, which is reviewed regularly by mentors. Assessment criteria include design process, project management, teamwork and communication.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"459e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4d9e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d9e5e91db24fc10be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"749e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"789e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"499e5e91db24fc10be4672f5f396191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Student teams give a presentation that pitches their final design solution, including its unique value. Assessment criteria will address the problem-solution, technical validation and communication.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"459e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4d9e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d9e5e91db24fc10be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"749e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c9e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d9e5e91db24fc10be4672f5f396190a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"School Assessments","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Each student is required to complete their school-specific assessment, comprised of three sub-tasks. For each sub-task, assessment criteria are related to the school's project and discipline, covering areas of design creation and evaluation, technical knowledge, project management and communication.
 
Task 1 - Preliminary Presentation 10% 

\n

Task 2 - Preliminary Report 20 % or Laboratory 20 %

\n

Task 3 - Final Report 30 % or Final Exam 30 %

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"459e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d9e5e91db24fc10be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"749e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"789e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c9e1e91db24fc10be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d9e5e91db24fc10be4672f5f3961913","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DESN2000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Design is one of the critical foundations of engineering and a main component in creating value. A good engineer has complex technical skills, but also creative skills, project management and teamworking skills, and knowledge of professional ethical standards in design. 

DESN2000 aims to further develop your skills in engineering design with a particular focus on the early stages, where innovative concepts are created in response to open-ended problems. These skills will be developed in the context of an engineering project, with a focus on three areas: (1) research techniques needed to understand design problems and discover concepts, (2) technical skills needed to build a concept, and (3) evaluation methods for evaluating the concept. Alongside the development of design skills, the course also aims to develop your readiness for professional practice by deepening your understanding and skills in effective project management, teamwork and communication.

The course builds on the teamwork, communication, and project management skills introduced in DESN1000. Skills learned in DESN2000 are further deepened in DESN3000, which will develop skills for managing design in commercial context.

With DESN1000 and DESN3000, DESN2000 provides design skills described in Engineers Australia’s Stage 1 Competencies, especially competencies 1.3, 1.5, 1.6; 2., 2.3; and 3.2 and 3.6.

Students who require DESN2000 should enrol in a specific term according to their Engineering Specialisation:

Term 2:
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Civil and Environmental Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Computer Science and Engineering

Term 3:
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Chemical Engineering
Students with specialisations offered by the School of Minerals and Energy Resources Engineering

Prerequisite Conditions:

  1. School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and enrolled in an MME streams (AEROAH, MECHAH, MANFAH, MTRNAH)
  2. School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and ELEC2141 and (COMP1511 or COMP1521)
  3. School of Chemical Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and CEIC2000 and (CHEM1821 or CHEM1021 or CHEM1041) 
  4. School of Civil and Environmental Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and enrolled in a Civil & Environmental Engineering streams (CVENAH, CVENBH, GMATDH)
  5. School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering: (DESN1000 or DPST1071) and SOLA 2051
  6. School of Computer Science and Engineering: (COMPBH and COMP1521 and (DESN1000 or DPST1071)) or (SENGAH/BINFAH and COMP 2521 and (DESN1000 or DPST1071))
  7. School of Minerals and Energy Resources Engineering: (MINEAH and (DESN1000 or DPST1071)) or (PETRAH and CEIC2001 and (DESN1000 or DPST1071))

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DESN3000 - Strategic Design Innovation","description":"

Over the last three decades design innovation has become strategic: success in design requires a strategy for managing the broader problems of innovation. As design has gained importance, it also has become relevant to a wide array of stakeholders. This has added complexity to the way in which design should be undertaken.


Design is an important instrument of innovation in manufacturing and service industries, as well as in public, semi-public and humanitarian organizations. These environments set many types of requirements for innovation, including price points, brand requirements, competition, technological and brand legacies, government regulations, and ethics. They almost always require an analysis of the ethical environment, which is often but not always coded into professional rules and regulations.


These environments are usually ambiguous, dynamic and reactive, and designers cannot control them. To innovate in these environments, designers need strategies for identifying and managing these contextual requirements.


DESN3000 teaches you skills in strategic design innovation. These include: skills for capturing the boundary conditions that create conditions for innovation; skills for creating design concepts that provide a fit to the strategic environment; skills for creating innovation strategies that help them to innovate in with multiple stakeholders who often have conflicting values and shifting interests; skills for identifying ethical problems involved in design decisions; and skills for managing teams and projects in strategic context.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Design proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Design proposal that provides a well articulated solution to the problem introduced in the project brief.Team evaluation is used to ensure equitable participation of members. Students complete a questionnaire, quantifying the relative contribution of team members. Qualitative comments provide a cross-reference for conflicting cases.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2baa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a7aa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"afaa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"afaa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"77aaace4dbe97810be4672f5f3961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students must keep a design journal that records and provides evidence of their design process and decisions involved in it. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a7aa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"afaa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"afaa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7baaace4dbe97810be4672f5f3961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Ethical stream","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students participate in an ethical stream in which they discuss ethical theories and specific ethical issues. They must write a 2300-2700 word report that requires research and uses formal ethical frameworks introduced in the course to discusses the ethical issues associated with the topic. It must consider both sides of any argument, identify the conclusions, and provide evidence of why they have been reached.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a7aa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3aaace4dbe97810be4672f5f396197f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Business plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students write a business plan that covers design, business and ethical aspects of their project. The plan will require empirical evidence to back up the argumentation regarding business, including target market analysis, product strategy, social and ethical constraints, and finance. Team evaluation is used to ensure equitable participation of members. Students complete a questionnaire, quantifying the relative contribution of team members. Qualitative comments provide a cross-reference for conflicting cases.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2baa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a7aa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"afaa6ce4dbe97810be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3aaace4dbe97810be4672f5f3961986","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/DESN3000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

contentlets.description:
Over the last three decades design innovation has become strategic: success in design requires a strategy for managing the broader problems of innovation. As design has gained importance, it also has become relevant to a wide array of stakeholders. This has added complexity to the way in which design should be undertaken.

Design is an important instrument of innovation in manufacturing and service industries, as well as in public, semi-public and humanitarian organizations. These environments set many types of requirements for innovation, including price points, brand requirements, competition, technological and brand legacies, government regulations, and ethics. They almost always require an analysis of the ethical environment, which is often but not always coded into professional rules and regulations.

These environments are usually ambiguous, dynamic and reactive, and designers cannot control them. To innovate in these environments, designers need strategies for identifying and managing these contextual requirements.

DESN3000 teaches you skills in strategic design innovation. These include: skills for capturing the boundary conditions that create conditions for innovation; skills for creating design concepts that provide a fit to the strategic environment; skills for creating innovation strategies that help them to innovate in with multiple stakeholders who often have conflicting values and shifting interests; skills for identifying ethical problems involved in design decisions; and skills for managing teams and projects in strategic context.
contentlets.title: Strategic Design Innovation
